bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 13, 1900

div1.p: Reed provides a description of his quarters at Camp Columbia and relates the typical schedule of his day. He laments the lack of rain for Emilie Lawrence Reed's garden. He discusses finances and political trouble in China.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 13, 1900
div1.opener:
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
July 13th, 1900
No. 17 --
Daughter's letter
of yesterday should have been numbered
16.
My own prescious wifie:
div1.p:
I wrote
to little daughter, on yesterday,
her birth-day. I thought of you
both a great deal & wonder-
ed how you were spending
the day. I hope very pleas-
antly. Your darling letter of
July 6th arrived on the 11th, but
I am expecting several with
tomorrow's (Saturday's) mail-
under our new mail sched-
ule, the interruption to the
arrival & departure of our
letters is very annoying.
You observe, dear Miss Wind-
-beaten Farmer-lady, that I am
not writing at 5.30 a.m. but
at 2.30 o'clock P.M. That very
early rising did pretty well
for a week or so, and then
it slowly, or rather, promptly
petered out! I found that
it didn't seem to enable me
to accomplish any more than
by the old system of getting up
at about 7 or a quarter to 7.
Now, I retire about 9.30 P.M.
and sleep till a quarter to 7
a.m. - Wander to the bath-
room in my pajamas & take
a fascinating shower-bath-
breakfast at 7.30 and get
to the laboratory, distant
about 75 yards, say at
8.15 to 8.30 a.m., where Iwe
stay till 11.30 & then come
home to rest for lunch-
Have I ever described my
quarters to you? I really can't
remember that I have done so.
I have two rooms, each 10 x 15-
a partition running from floor
to about 7 1/2 ft. so as to leave
good circulation of air over the
partition, should the door between
the rooms be shut,(which it never
is). My front room looks north
to the sea & has a large door
reaching from floor to ceiling, &
on either side of this two a good-
sized window with glass sash
& a heavy outside wooden
shutters- The rear room has
the same high door & two openings
(windows) but no sash-only
heavy shutters close these-
In my front room, I have a
long wooden table stretching nearly
across the room, which answers
for my writing desk & for official
papers- Here, also, sits my lamp,
on the other side is a long shelf
on which I put my books-
In the back, I have a good hosp-
ital bed with mosquito-bar
& a small wooden table for
a wash-stand- good shelves
for my underwear & a place
for my clothes to hang. A small
shelf in one corner holds my
shaving outfit and completes
the furniture, barring a couple
of comfortable folding chairs.
You thus see, lovie, dear, that
I am living quite like a
bachelor & that, as my wants
are few, I cannot complain
of a lack of necessary Comforts.
In your last, you spoke of
its being so very hot and
said that your thermometer
in your bed-room registered
84°- Well, I don't call to-day
particularly warm here,
but the thermometer as I
write points to 83°! Of course,
it can't be called a cold
day- There is a good breeze
blowing and this serves, I
suppose, to make us feel more com-
fortable than we otherwise
would expect. I don't think
that your month's expenses
were very high- I had ex-
pected that it would cost
$100.00 to $115.00 per month- Of course,
Woodward & Lothnop's bill should
be charged largely to my ac-
count- If you and dear little
piano-player are getting some-
thing good to eat, I shall be
quite satisfied with your list
of expenses- Am so sorry for
my darling wifie's sake, that
no rain had fallen & that your
garden was looking so badly.
Perhaps, by this writing, the
rains have come and things
begin to promise better.
I still think that you will have
a pretty fair garden.
Does the clover still blossom
as much as ever? or has
the Kentucy Blue begun to
wrestle with it? How did
the little maples & the ever-
greens stand the drouth?
Here, sweetheart, I am getting
sleepy and must take my after-
noon's nap- will add a
postscript in the morning
before the Postman comes.
Saturday morning - 14th. Here I am
trying to get my letter ready
for the postman and have only
a few minutes- How beau-
tifully I slept last night,
lovie, dear! Drs Carroll, La-
zaer & I went in on the
7 P.M train to Havana, in
order to pay our respects
to Gen. Wood and came out on
the 9 P.M, getting home in time
for any “early to bed”- Isn't
it sad about Mrs. Wood's
younger sister being shut
up in Pekin and probably
massacred by the Chinese
Mob? I asked Gen. Wood
whether he had any later & more hopeful
news, but he said no; that
all the despatches pointed
to the death of the foreign
colony- Of course, before
this reaches you, we may hear
some thing more definite-
I sincerely hope that affairs
may not be so bad in China
as reported - The 8th Inf,
leave here on Monday - The
regiment is under orders
for China- Uncle Samuel
seems to have his hands
full these later days! We
had a glorious shower, last
afternoon, followed by a very
cool evening- This morning
it is delightful - and I am
as hungry as a bear! If I
couldnt only have one of my
sweet Farmer-lady's Keewaydin
breakfasts! Love to Helen & Aunt
Jane, if they are with you- Love
and kisses for my own precious
baby girls-
